turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Just a boid in a gilded cage -

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: You heard me. A bird in a gilded cage.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Aw, you've been reading a lot of cheap tabloids. Anne and myself are going to move downtown in a nice little flat, we're gonna forget all about this social stuff, and we're gonna be known as Mr. and Mrs. Stew Smith. How do you like that?

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: And live on your salary, I suppose?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah, live on my salary - that is, until I finish writing my play.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: What play?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: My play.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: The one about the Siberian bloodhound?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Siberian bloodhound?  No. That's been all rewritten. It's laid in Araby now.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Araby?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Araby, my eye!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry to see a good reporter go blooey  Let me know when you're quitting.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm not quitting!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: 'For he's only a bird in a gilded cage, a beautiful sight to see'  Tweet, tweet - ha, ha

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: How do you like your bath, sir?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I like my bath all right. How do you like your bath?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: I'm your valet, sir. Dawson is the name, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You're my what?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Your valet, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you! I'll do that for you some time. That's very sweet. Say listen, what did you say your name was?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Dawson, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Dawson, huh? Was I very drunk last night?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Drunk, sir?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes. I must have been pretty much plastered if I hired a valet.

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Oh, but you didn't engage me, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Did you take anything out of those pants?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Oh no, sir!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What are you doing fooling around in here?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Miss Schuyler - I mean, Mrs. Smith - she engaged me this morning, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Say, you are nice. You're all right. You'd make a good wife.

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: But not for me!  Though I like you well enough. You're a nice fellow. You're all right. But I'm sorry I don't need any valleys today.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Are you trying to tell me that I need someone to help me put on my pants and button them up?

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Quite so. Quite.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now I'm sorry. I appreciate your efforts. But I don't need anybody to help me button my pants - I've been buttoning my pants for thirty years all right, and I can button 'em with one hand as a matter of fact.

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Now Mr. Smith, now please

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: All right, outside!

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: I beg your pardon, sir?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Outside!

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: I think I understand, sir. You mean you want me to go?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: There you are. You caught on. You see, you're nice and you're smart too. You caught on right away. Outside! Go on! Outside! And don't come back!

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: That's a canary, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's a canary! Who brought that in here? Canary, huh? Go on, get that out of here. Get that out of here!

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Yes, sir. Very good, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: A bird! A bird in a gilded cage! Get that thing out of here!

turns.speaker: DAWSON
turns.text: Yes sir!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: I'm Miss Wilson - Mrs. Schuyler's social secretary.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I was sent from the Post in place of our social editor.

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: Yes, of course. Miss Ramsey telephoned me. Well, what would you like to have?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Why, a list of the guests. That's the usual thing, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: Yes, of course. I'll get it for you

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: That's a lovely dress.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Thank you.  Where is Mr. Smith?

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: Mr. Smith? Oh, you mean Ann Schuyler's husband?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: He's probably very tired. You see, he's had to meet all these people personally tonight.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I bet.

turns.speaker: MISS WILSON
turns.text: You newspaper people have a lot of fun with him, don't you? What is it you call him - the Cinderella Man?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Stew, your hands are shaking. You've been drinking again.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Come on, come on. Here they come, Gallagher! Here they come!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: The boss is getting hoarse.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: There's the third one. If I don't get the last one, there's a certain sob sister I know that's going to get a kick right in the . . . oh! Whoops, almost had that.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: You're sure going to be poison to that Junior Leaguer[4] from now on!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I hope not . . . I've got to call on her this morning!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: You what?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, I must drop in on the mad wench. Her wounds need soothing.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: For heaven's sake, Stew, are you completely bats? What for? I thought the story was cold. You can't go back there.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, the story is cold, but I'm not. I'm sizzling - look! Psst!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: And with it came love! Oh Gallagher, you've got to meet her. She's it

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: and that

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: and those and them.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Well, I've seen her pictures, and I don't think she's so hot.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, you don't appreciate it. Her pictures don't do her justice. Why, Gallagher, she's queenly - she is queenly - and I know queens!  And oh, has she got herself a nose - and I know noses too. That little snozzle of hers is the berries, I tell you. And is she cute when she throws that little snozzle to the high heavens!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Of course I haven't got a nose.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, sure. You've got a nose, Gallagher. You've got a nose. But there's different women, Gallagher. You know, like brewery horses and thoroughbreds.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: On now, Stew, don't be too hard on her. I wouldn't call her a brewery horse.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher! She's the real McCoy!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: And the rest of us are truck horses?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: There you go, talking like a woman!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Well!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, you're my pal, aren't you? Then don't turn female on me.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, well, well! Gallagher, old pal! There you are. What did you run away for?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I didn't run away.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, you ran away. Aren't you going to congratulate a guy?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Sure. I wish you all the luck in the world, pal.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Thanks, thanks.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I hope you'll be very happy.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh sure, we'll be happy. What's the matter with your eyes?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: It's the smoke.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Joe! A little snifter.  Say, wasn't I a lucky guy to fall into a girl like that, huh?  Look at that! I don't know how I rate that, Gallagher. Gosh, there's a swell girl. I want you to meet her.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Who me? She wouldn't want to meet me. I'm just an old load of hay.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Ah! Thank you, Joe.  Tell you what - we'll have one of those parties down at your house - one of those spaghetti parties, you know. Gee, we haven't had one of those in a long time, have we Gallagher?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Not since you broke into society.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Remember the time we had a spaghetti party, and while I was serving the spaghetti I dropped it on the floor, and while those mugs weren't looking, I picked it up and served it to them anyway! Remember that? Yes, Anne would love that.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Do you think your wife would walk up three flights of stairs just to eat out of paper plates?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Who - Anne? Sure, Anne would love that.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Remember, she's a Schuyler.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now get this, Gallagher - Smith. That's the name.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: My error.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, if she doesn't want to come, I'll come down alone.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Oh no, you won't, Mr. Smith. You're a married man now. Mother always warned me never to run around with married men.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Say, what kind of a pal are you? You're not going to leave me flat?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Oh, I'll call you up some time. And if your social duties permit - why -

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Cut that out. Just because I'm married - there's no reason for that.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Don't pay attention to him, Stew. He doesn't know what he's talking about.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Pay attention? I'm not paying any attention to him. You think that guy could get me upset? Hah! Not that mug. He's a tough mug - hard, cynical. He doesn't know the fine things in life - that guy.  A bird in a gilded cage, huh? It's getting so a guy can't step out without being called a magnolia. Stew Smith, a magnolia! Not me. Say, I'm not going to hang around and be a speakeasy rat all my life! I'll tell you that. Not me, not me. I'm going to step out and mean something in this world. You watch me.  Say, am I a lucky guy to be near Anne Schuyler?  I've been hit with a carload of horseshoes, and believe me I know it. Lucky, I'll say I'm lucky!  Don't you think I'm lucky, Gallagher?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Sure - I think so, Stew.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I knew you would, pal.  A bird in a gilded cage, eh?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: How is her family going to feel about it?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Her family? Oh, they'll be all right. I'll bring them around.  Gilded cage?!  Besides, I'm not marrying her family. Stew Smith in a gilded cage! Stew Smith? Ha!  That mug. What does he know?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Mr. Smith, I've read some of your plays and I'd like an autograph.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, well! If it isn't my old friend! Turn around, gal! Let's get a look at you.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: There you are!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, daughter of the slums - how did you get out of the ghetto?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I'm pinch-hitting for our society editor tonight. I wanted to see some life in the raw.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Aw, you wanted to see some life in the raw, huh? Well gal, I'm afraid we ain't got no raw life up here.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Well, I'll have to look someplace else.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No, no! Maybe we could interest you in some well done butterflies, or perhaps some slightly fried pansies, or better still, some stuffed shirts. And guaranteed every one of them will give you a good stiff pain in the neck.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Say, who's been tying your ties lately? It looks rotten.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gee Gallagher, do you look good! What are you doing to yourself?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What did you do to that hair? And where did you get that dress?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I dyed one and washed the other.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, you dyed one and washed the other. Well! You certainly look good.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Don't turn around now - but there's a very beautiful girl up there who seems to be staring at us.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Staring at us?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: My mistake - she's glaring.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Must be my wife.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: They all consider me just as one of the boys.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Right!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm sorry, Gallagher - really, I am sorry.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Oh, that's all right, Stew. Forget it. As far as she's concerned, I'm just part of the hired help.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No, no. Strange, I've never seen Anne act that way before.  It's funny I never thought to tell her you were a girl, isn't it?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, Gallagher! Glad to see you.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Hello, Stew.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Hello, Hank. How are you?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I'm sorry, Stew. I asked Hank, and Hank did the rest.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I see. Hank brought them all. That's all right. We'll give them a drink and throw 'em out. How's that?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe! Give them one drink and throw 'em out!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You know what I should do with you? I should sock you right in that funny little nose.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yes - and I'd love it.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: How far have you gotten?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, I've just been able to get off that Norway coast - so far.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Well, you're not getting your play done, but you're certainly covering a lot of territory.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Haven't I covered some territory? It feels like I've been on a Cook's Tour[18] some place.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Stewart, have you ever been to Old Madrid?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Been where?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: To Old Madrid.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Never even been to New Madrid.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Then how do you expect to write about it?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh - draw on my imagination, I suppose.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Did Conrad draw on his imagination?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Did who?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Conrad.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What do you know about Conrad?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I don't know a thing about him, but isn't he the one you're always yelling about?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Isn't he the one that always writes about things - only the things he knows about?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Didn't he go to sea before he wrote about it?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Then why don't you write about something you know?  Write about yourself and Anne. The poor boy who marries a rich girl - now there's a swell theme.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gee, that's an idea, Gallagher. That's an idea there. I wonder now...

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Oh, sure. She'd make a beautiful heroine...

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: And there's her mother - and what a character that old dame would make with her double-strength - and that lawyer friend of theirs - he'd make a great villain - and there's you!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: What could I be?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You could be something.  I've got an idea, Gallagher. Let's get this set. That's a great idea for a play. Pal, get me a cigarette, will you?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Here you are.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: All right, thanks. Now, let's see. How will I start? Hey pal, how would you start?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now Gallagher, if we could only get a great scene - a tremendously emotional scene - something that would just wring the hearts out of the public - to bring the curtain down in the second act - that would be okay. Couldn't dig one out of your hat some place, could you?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Nope - afraid I'm all out of tricks tonight.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now, we've got it right up to where the boy's wearing his white spats and going to teas and the frau enters - how's that?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I wouldn't worry too much about it, Stew. She'll see it your way.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Huh?  Oh, I'm not worrying about her - I'm worrying about that second act curtain, that's all.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Hey, Gallagher!

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: How about my breakfast? How do you expect me to ring a curtain down on an empty stomach?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: It'll be ready in a minute.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Never mind that. If you can't get my breakfast ready - and can't get here on time in the morning - then you can go get yourself another job.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Sorry, boss

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Don't be sorry. Just get the breakfast, that's all.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Grayson - Anne's lawyer.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: What did he want?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher, that guy just dropped by to give us a great opening for the third act.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It's a swell idea, Gallagher. How's this?  The wife's family lawyer comes to see the kid, see - to talk over the divorce. Then this guy insults the poor but honest boy by offering him alimony - so the kid gets sore, socks the lawyer in the nose and throws him out. How's that for the beginning of the third act, huh?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Well, from now on the play will be easy. All you have to do is bring the wife back, have her say she's sorry, and then your play's over.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: What other girl?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: The little O'Brien girl, of course - the one you suggested in the story.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: But that's ridiculous! You can't make a sudden change like that.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher, what are you going to do - tell me how to write a play?

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: There's nothing sudden about that  He's always loved the girl, but he was such a sap he didn't have sense enough to tell her. Well, that's all right - we can fix that. He will go to the little O'Brien girl, and - here, I'll show you.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Nice set of Conrads you have out there, Mrs. Schuyler. I was just glancing through this one.  What's Michael tearing the paper about?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Just a habit. Mr. Schuyler is a bit put out by all the rumors going around.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Rumors? Rumors? Since when is a breach-of-promise case a rumor?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: No breach-of-promise case has been filed. The matter has been settled out of court.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh I see, but Gloria doesn't seem to be satisfied with the twenty thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, well. That takes it out of the rumor class, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: We admit nothing. However, I have a little statement all prepared.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: A statement? Good.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I have it here.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: The man from the Tribune seemed perfectly satisfied.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Who, Bingy? Yeah, Bingy would. He never saw fifty dollars before. You could have bought him for six bits. Funny thing about Bingy. The more he gets - the more he prints. He looks stupid, doesn't he? But oh how smart he gets when he bends over a typewriter.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I think you'd better go.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Go?! Wait a minute - that's a great story! Newspaper reporter was forcibly ejected from Schuyler Mansion, and

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I've tried to stop the evening papers, but it's useless.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You quit trying to stop anybody

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Well, at best you might deny it.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Why deny it? The more you deny, the more they print. Let them alone! The thing to do is to sit still and keep our traps shut.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Traps shut!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Certainly! I'll take care of this guy Bingy myself, personally.  Now what are you crying about?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Hello, Smith.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Holy jumping swordfish!

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I suppose you know why I came?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No, I have no idea - unless some of the silver-ware is missing.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Now don't be absurd, Smith  May I come in?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Surely, come right in.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Thanks. May I sit down?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Surely, sit down. If I had known you were coming, I would have thrown you up a waffle.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I don't eat waffles.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You don't.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Anne asked me to come and see you about the divorce.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: She did?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: She wants me to arrange the financial settlement.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Listen Grayson, I've got 106 bucks and 75 cents in the bank. Now Anne can have any part of that she wants, but she'd better hurry because I'm spending it awfully fast.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: You don't seem to understand. Anne doesn't expect anything from you.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Wait a minute. Do I get from you that she wants to pay me alimony?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: That's putting it crudely, but

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Remember what I told you about that twentieth crack? All right, you've just made it. Before you go unconscious I want you to get this through your nut.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I beg your pardon.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Unconscious. You know, when you don't know anything. Your natural state. There are some people - you can't buy their self-respect for a bucket of shekels - well, I happen to be one of those guys.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: We just thought that

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Don't think. Let me do all the thinking. Now you go back to that Schuyler outfit and tell them that I didn't marry that dame for her dough and I don't want any of her dough now. I was too poor to buy her a wedding present when we got married, so I'm giving her a divorce for a wedding present. Now, stand up!

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: And now for that twentieth crack

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Fine, but kinda thirsty.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Come right in - I'll get you a drink.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Okay - you remember Joe

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I sort of invited him along to bend an elbow. You don't mind, do you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It's all right. Bring him in.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Come in, Joe. It's all right.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Hello, Joe.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm sorry nobody could come.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: The rest of the gang had to get out the morning edition - but they'll be down later.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now Hank, are you sure they're coming?  It will be lonesome without them.  Smythe, take this crowd in there and give them a drink. And find out what the boys in the back room want!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: What is it, Smythe?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Pardon me, madam - but what am I to say to the newspapermen?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Oh, Smythe, some bicarbonate of soda, quick - double strength. I know those news mongrels[3] will upset me.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I've anticipated it, madame. The bicarbonate is ready.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Some bicarbonate - quick!

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Double strength!

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Double-strength!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: "Cinderella Man Grows Hair On Chest!"

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Pardon me, madam. They phoned through from the Mayor's committee to remind you it's past the hour for the reception.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Are the cars ready?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: They've been ready for the last half hour.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Smythe, you've been drinking.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I have. Double-strength!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Dexter Grayson, you told me it was only ten thousandand you didn't even get those letters from that Jezebel!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, so you did give her ten thousand dollars, eh? and there are letters...

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I was just trying to decide the color of Anne's eyes. I can't tell whether they're blue, or whether they're violet. What would you say, Mrs. Schuyler?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Why

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Indeed? Perhaps he will do me a great favor.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: With pleasure, Madame!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Get out of here.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Nobody seems to want to do anything  Why not ask me? Perhaps I can offer a suggestion. Do what about what?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: About what? Your marriage to Anne!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, my marriage to Anne. Now Mrs. Schuyler, we don't want you to go to any trouble about that. We just want the usual blessings, that's all.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Stop calling me Mother!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: All right, Grandma

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: This man's impossible! I can't talk to him. Grayson, let's go where we can talk - hic!  See what you've done to me!?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Good morning, everybody  Well, maybe it isn't a good morning, huh?  Anne, did you ever get the feeling that there was someone else in the room with you?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Have you seen this?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes - the worm!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: He's a worm - and I'm gonna step on him!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: To engage in a brawl! A cheap, common brawl, in my own home! "I wear the pants!" The pants ! Not even the trousers!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: And you struck him right here in our house?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes, I'm sorry, I struck him right here in your house. And I'll strike anybody in anybody's house that calls me a Cinderella Man.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's the fourteenth crack you've made to me. I'm keeping count. When you get to twenty, I'm gonna sock you right on the nose. As a matter of fact, I ought to sock you right now.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Anne Schuyler, are you going to sit there and watch this man insult us? Haven't you any decency left?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: What's going on here? Who is this woman?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Joan of Arc! What's it to you?

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Heavens! The man's insane!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure I'm insane, but I've got some good news for you.  This magnolia is leaving your sweet smelling vanilla joint. This bird in a cage is gonna button his own pants from now on. And that is what is known as telling the mother- in-law.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: There are no gentlemen on the Tribune.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I understand, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now, now Jeeves.[5] Was that nice? Was that being a gentleman, Jeeves? Was it, Jeeves? Your name is Jeeves, isn't it?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: The name is Smythe.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe! Well, well, well! With a Y , huh?  Congratulations! What a small world. Brothers under livery. Shake!  Now, as a Smith to a Smythe

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Mrs. Schuyler is not at home.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I know, I know. I waited outside till she went out. She's a very nice lady, but we don't vibrate well together.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: But I

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now the lady said you may go

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Well done, sir. Very neat.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's what I think of it, Bingy!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe, the - er - gentleman is leaving.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Did you call, sir?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe, come here. I want to talk to you.  Come on, Smythe, talk to me. Smythe, I'm going nuts. I'm going nuts in this house! This big . . . come on, I'm not going to hurt you. Come on, what's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Shhh! Do you hear something?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You try it.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Me, sir?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No, that's enough. I just wanted you to get the idea. Now you know. This house is haunted.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: No, sir!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes. Have you looked in the closets all over . . .?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Found no skeletons?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It's haunted just the same.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe, what do you do with yourself - I mean, when you're not carrying those double-strength - what do you do with yourself?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Well, sir, I putter.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe! I mean - when you're alone and want to amuse yourself, then what?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I just putter.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Hmmm, you just putter. Do you have to have a putter to putter?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Oh no, sir. I putter with me hands.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, isn't that nice? You just go right ahead and putter with your hands. That's all right. How do you do it?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Well sir, I'll show you.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: That's puttering, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No! Well, well, well! That's all right, if you like it. Can anybody do that?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Oh no, sir. Some people are natural putterers. Others can never master it.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh my. You mean, some people are born and never will become putterers?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh my, wouldn't that be tragic? To know that you could never be a putterer.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: How about me?  Do you think if I concentrated and put my whole soul into it, that some day I might be a putterer?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: You sir? Uh-uh. You could never be a putterer. Not a good putterer, sir.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, if I couldn't be a good putterer, I wouldn't want to putter. But why? What makes you think I couldn't be a good putterer?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Well sir, to be a putterer, one's mind must be at ease. A person with a problem could never be a putterer. For instance, sir, a fish can putter in water but not on land because he'd be out of place. An eagle can putter around a rugged mountaintop but not in a cage, because he'd be restless and unhappy. Now sir, if you will pardon me, with all due respect, sir, as a Smythe to a Smith, you are an eagle in a cage.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: A bird in a gilded cage?

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's all I wanted to know!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Smythe, I'll get this. I'm expecting some friends.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Very good, sir.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: It isn't done, gentlemen! It isn't done, I say! It isn't done!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, Gallagher, you certainly took no chances, did you?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I just love you in that sweater Mary-Sue. It's so flattering.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: I put blueberries in them just the way you like.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Actually--I'm not real ... hungry.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Oh nonsense young lady. You're going to start your day with a nice big breakfast.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Mary Sue?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What goes on up at Lover's Lane?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well, you hear all these things lately. You know--kids spending so much time up there ...  Is it holding hands? That kind of thing?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Yeah ...  That--and ...

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: It doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: No. I want to know.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: ... Sex.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: You sure you want to know this?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Yes ...  It's just that ...

turns.speaker: JENNIFER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Well ...  ... Your father would never do anything like that.

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Bud. Mary Sue ... Breakfast is on the table.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: We're in Pleasantville?

turns.speaker: BETTY
turns.text: Bu-ud ... Mary Sue ... Your breakfast is getting cold.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: It can't be possible.
